author: @gamingbible
title: Steam free download is strange mix of Stardew Valley and Resident Evil
text:
If you are a fan of Stardew Valley but sometimes wished it had more horror elements, then you are in luck as this upcoming release is free to try out right now.
Combining the farming sim elements of Stardew Valley with the horror themes found in Resident Evil, We Harvest Shadows is an upcoming first-person farming horror allegory from developer David Wehle.
Check out the trailer for Stardew Valley below!
This single-player title will see you become a recluse, build up your farm, and survive the lonely nights - and its demo is now available to try out for free courtesy of Steam.
Advert
We Harvest Shadows will see players take on the role of Garrett, a man who once lived in the city but has now found himself in charge of an abandoned farm.
He thinks the world just may be better off without him in it and so this emotional narrative adventure is so much more than your average farming simulator.
Especially as when the night draws close, Garrett no longer feels alone; is something really stalking him from the shadows?
By day, you will fix up your house, care for livestock, improve the land and explore the hundreds of acres that you now find yourself surrounded by.
Advert
“Taking inspiration both from slow-burn P.T.-style psychological horror games and Edith Finch-style personal first-person titles, this game plays on poignant horror themes to gradually imagine a terrifying vision that Garrett must save himself from—until the soul-shaking end,” the official synopsis reads.
With slow-burn horror (no reliance on jump scares here), a gorgeous cinematic soundtrack, survival elements that don't just rely on hunger and thirst, and even a story that will see you needing to piece together Garrett’s past, this farming simulator is not one to miss out on.
We Harvest Shadows has not yet received a full release date but it is now available to download as a free demo over on Steam.
Topics: Steam, Resident Evil, Stardew Valley, PC
topics: Arts, Culture and Entertainment->arts and entertainment

author: MarketScreener
title: Britain promises up to 21.7 billion pounds for cleaner energy - MarketScreener
text:
LONDON (Reuters) - Britain will provide funding of up to 21.7 billion pounds ($28.46 billion) over 25 years to develop carbon capture and storage (CCS) and hydrogen technology in northern England, the government said on Friday.
Britain has a climate target to reach net zero emissions by 2050 and has said CCS will be needed to curb emissions from energy intensive industrial sectors as well as to create jobs.
"This game-changing technology will bring 4,000 good jobs and billions of private investment into communities across Merseyside and Teesside, igniting growth in these industrial heartlands and powering up the rest of the country," Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves said in a statement.
CCS involves the capture of emissions from power plants and industry to allow them to be stored underground but has been slow to take off due to the high cost of projects.
Britain's previous conservative government, which was voted out of office in July, had in 2023 promised 20 billion pounds of CCS funding that was never fully awarded.
The two sites in northern England will have a combined annual carbon capture capacity of 8.5 million metric tons a year, equivalent to taking four million cars off the road, the government said.
The HyNet North West cluster in Merseyside seeks to capture emissions from industrial plants and store them in depleted gas fields in the Irish Sea. It is being developed by a consortium led by Italian energy group Eni.
"HyNet... will decarbonise one of the key energy-intensive industrial districts as well as unlock significant economic growth in this region of the UK," Eni CEO Claudio Descalzi said in a statement.
Oil and gas majors Equinor and BP are involved in developing a project in Teesside that would store captured emissions under the North Sea.
($1 = 0.7625 pounds)
(Reporting By Susanna Twidale; editing by Barbara Lewis)
By Susanna Twidale
Share © Reuters - 2024

author: VNExplorer
title: Habitat: l'enseigne d'ameublement placée en liquidation judiciaire
text:
Le tribunal de commerce de Bobigny prononce ce 28 décembre la liquidation judiciaire de l’enseigne Habitat, qui souffrait de difficultés financières depuis plusieurs années. 380 salariés seront licenciés.
L’histoire d’Habitat arrive à son épilogue. Comme l’annonce Libération, des informations que RMC est en mesure de confirmer, le tribunal de commerce de Bobigny prononce ce jeudi 28 décembre le placement de l’enseigne d’ameublement et de décoration en liquidation judiciaire, 20 jours après son redressement judiciaire. Cette décision implique le licenciement de 380 employés.
L’enseigne d’ameublement a été placée le 28 décembre en liquidation judiciaire sur décision du tribunal de commerce de Bobigny.
Des difficultés économiques insurmontables Le 30 novembre dernier, Habitat avait demandé son redressement judiciaire, évoquant “des difficultés financières profondes” liées, entre autres, à l’inflation et à une baisse de la fréquentation de ses magasins. Dix jours plus tard, le 15 décembre, une demande de liquidation judiciaire était cette fois demandée par le tribunal.
L’état détérioré des comptes a provoqué la chute de l’entreprise. Les syndicats pointent du doigt l’entrepreneur investisseur Thierry Le Guénic, qui avait acquis l’enseigne en 2020, et l’estiment responsable. Il avait également acquis l’enseigne d’habillement Burton of London, qui a été elle aussi placée en redressement judiciaire.
L’homme d’affaires a admis dans une lettre adressée à l’AFP ne pas avoir “réussi à relever ce challenge, tout comme les précédents actionnaires”. Il se défend toutefois d’avoir évité “tout plan social” et d’avoir investi plus de 12 millions d’euros dans l’ouverture de points de vente et dans le numérique.
380 postes supprimés Cette décision du tribunal de commerce de Bobigny provoque le licenciement de plus de 380 salariés. Certains ont déjà manifesté leur inquiétude quant à leur avenir, un certain nombre d’entre eux ayant passé leur carrière au service de l’enseigne et se trouvant aux portes de la retraite.
Fondée en 1964 par le designer britannique Terence Conran, Habitat entendait proposer des meubles et des objets de décoration à des prix abordables. En 2022, l’entreprise avait généré un chiffre d’affaires de 65 millions d’euros. La société mère, Habitat Design International, qui emploie 68 personnes, affichait de son côté un chiffre d’affaires de 51,8 millions d’euros la même année.

author: VNExplorer
title: Maine's Democrat Governor Janet Mills is branded a LIAR by the National Weather Service after she claimed they didn't warn her historic storm would bring up to six inches of rain
text:
The NWS hit back after the governor said the organization did not adequately predict the flooding brought by last week's winter stormThe state is continuing its recovery effort in the aftermath of last Monday's severe storm
Maine’s Democrat Governor Janet Mills has been branded a liar by the National Weather Service after claiming its forecasters didn’t warn her about a historic storm.
The esteemed federal agency lashed Mills after she was slammed for failing to adequately warn locals that up to half a foot of rain would fall on December 18, causing huge floods and leaving 400,000 without power.
Mills put her foot in it last Wednesday while touring flood-battered Kennebec County, saying: ‘The National Weather Service did not predict five or six inches of rain in any community in Maine.’
But a NWS spokesman said the 75 year-old lawmaker was talking nonsense, insisting state and local officials had been briefed about the impending inundation on December 15.
And on Sunday the 17th – the day before the storm – the weather service met with state officials to further brief them on expected flooding, winds, and impact to the state’s coast line.
Governor Mills deflected blame for Maine’s lack of preparedness for the recent storm to the National Weather Service. pic.twitter.com/egh14zozHl
— The Maine Wire (@TheMaineWire) December 20, 2023
Governor Janet Mills is catching flack for saying the National Weather Service did not adequately predict the severe dimensions of the winter storm that hit Maine last week
Cars are flooded in a parking lot at the Hathaway Creative Center alongside the Kennebec River, Tuesday, Dec. 19, 2023, in Waterville, Maine
Mills and her office have not yet responded to the NWS’s claims that she is a liar.
Images of the storm’s aftermath show cars hanging off extremely damaged roads, intense, murky floodwaters that swept other vehicles away, collapsed construction sites, and downed trees and powerlines.
The storm, which Mills called ‘an extraordinary event,’ barreled into the Northeast on Monday, knocking out power to hundreds of thousands of people, forcing flight cancellations, and killing at least four people.
Wind gusts reaches nearly 70 miles per hour, which Mills also said the National Weather Service did not predict.
‘The National Weather Service did not predict 68-70 mile an hour winds in any area of Maine,’ she said. ‘It was an extraordinary event.’
In fact, the NWS does seem to have predicted possible winds of 65-70 miles per hour at the same time that they predicted four-to-six inches of rain.
Earlier this week, Mills announced the launch of an online resource for Maine residents who were hit hard by the flood and other storm damage.
The Maine Flood Resources and Assistance Hub was launched on Tuesday. According to the governor’s office, it will aggregate ‘information, resources, and assistance’ for those impacted by the storm.
Propane tanks set free by flood waters discharge gas as they float on the Kennebec River through Augusta, Maine, Tuesday, Dec. 19, 2023
Nathan Sennett and Tori Grasse retrieve furniture from a flooded patio near the Kennebec River, Tuesday, Dec. 19, 2023, in Hallowell, Maine
A car floats in a flooded parking lot at the Hathaway Creative Center alongside the Kennebec River in Waterville, Maine
A man observes the flooded Kennebec River on December 19 in Maine
The announcement of the hub arrived after civil states of emergency were declared in 14 of 16 counties in Maine.
The severity of the storm’s damage prompted Mills to request a Major Disaster Declaration from President Joe Biden, which will allow federal resources to supplement the recovery efforts led by the state.
‘In the wake of last week’s storm, my Administration has launched the Maine Flood Resources and Assistance Hub to help Maine people with questions they may have about property damage, road safety, tree removal, and more,’ Mills said in the news release about the resource hub.
‘We will update this website as more information becomes available as part of our effort to do all we can to support the swiftest possible recovery of Maine communities.’
The governor also announced Tuesday that the Federal Emergency Management Agency has approved the Maine Emergency Management Agency’s request to begin an preliminary damage assessment, which is the first formal step toward request the aforementioned Major Disaster Declaration.

author: Iulia Cazan
title: ONU ataca a África por actitudes ante el aborto - ZENIT - Espanol
text: (ZENIT Noticias / Nueva York, 28.12.2023).- Los grupos abortistas internacionales y las agencias de la ONU están influyendo en el desarrollo de programas de propaganda masiva en África. Junto con funcionarios gubernamentales, están llevando a cabo campañas de promoción a gran escala para incluir el aborto como servicio sanitario esencial. El Fondo de Población de las Naciones Unidas (UNFPA) y la Organización Mundial de la Salud (OMS) publicaron [un informe](https://reliefweb.int/report/world/unlocking-future-advancing-universal-sexual-and-reproductive-health-and-rights-within-universal-health-coverage-east-and-southern-africa) en el que se comprometen a acoplar los servicios sanitarios y el aborto en el sudeste de África y que ningún país de esa región, como Angola, Botsuana, Kenia, Malawi y Uganda, entre otros, podrá alcanzar la atención sanitaria universal sin una atención sexual y reproductiva universal. El informe admite que el acceso a la anticoncepción, la atención al embarazo y los tratamientos del VIH ya están parcialmente incluidos en muchos paquetes de atención sanitaria universal de esa región. Aun así, las agencias de la ONU presionan para que se incluyan el acceso al aborto y la educación sexual integral como componentes «esenciales» de la atención sanitaria. Para garantizar un acceso generalizado al aborto en la región, el informe recomienda «fortalecer el ecosistema de salud digital y las intervenciones de autocuidado relacionadas». A principios de este año, la [OMS lanzó una aplicación móvil](https://unric.org/en/who-comprehensive-abortion-care-tool-mobile-app/) para ayudar a los profesionales sanitarios a ofrecer una mejor «atención» del aborto a las mujeres embarazadas. La aplicación «toma las características individuales de las pacientes y genera evaluaciones o recomendaciones específicas para cada paciente» y ayuda a facilitar el apoyo remoto a las pacientes para «asistir» a las mujeres mientras practican abortos en casa. El informe de la OMS y la UNFPA también señala que un factor crucial para garantizar una «atención integral de la salud sexual y reproductiva» es realizar un trabajo de «clarificación de valores» para los proveedores. Este tipo de trabajo intenta «desestigmatizar» el aborto entre el personal médico y animarles a practicarlo. Está claro que mucho personal médico de África se opone al aborto. Ipas, una organización internacional cuyo propósito expreso es promover el aborto en todo el mundo, tiene un plan de estudios completo al respecto, el Ipas Values Clarification for Action and Transformation (VCAT), y lo utiliza para derribar las creencias médicas y religiosas sobre el aborto en toda África. En [un reciente comunicado de prensa](https://www.ipas.org/news/in-the-democratic-republic-of-congo-policymakers-commit-to-including-abortion-in-universal-health-coverage/), Ipas proclamó su victoria en la República Democrática del Congo. La atención integral del aborto está ahora incluida en el programa de salud universal y se jactó de haber sido uno de los factores clave para que esto ocurriera. Dicho cambio de política no se logró únicamente movilizando a las organizaciones de la sociedad civil. Ipas ofreció capacitación en SSR a funcionarios gubernamentales, incluido el personal del Ministerio de Salud de la RDC. Ipas dijo que pudo encontrar partidarios dentro del gobierno. Está claro que el dinero desempeñó un papel muy importante en el cambio. El director de Ipas en el Congo dijo lo siguiente: «el presupuesto gubernamental existente no puede financiar la atención integral del aborto… Ipas está trabajando para asegurar esta financiación faltante». Es probable que la financiación que falta proceda de la administración Biden. Al celebrar el Día de la Cobertura Universal de Salud, Ipas dijo que «de la Asamblea General de las Naciones Unidas, en septiembre, surgió una poderosa declaración conjunta firmada por 60 países, que hace un llamado para que la salud y los derechos sexuales y reproductivos sean un componente esencial de la Cobertura Universal de Salud». Sin embargo, no se trata de un documento de la Asamblea General de la ONU. Un derecho internacional al aborto nunca ha surgido de la Asamblea General y un número significativo de miembros de la ONU han realizado constantemente declaraciones en la ONU aclarando que no consideran que el término «salud y derechos sexuales y reproductivos» incluya el aborto.

author: @teletica
title: Fiscalía frena proyecto residencial que se construía ilegalmente en bosque protegido
text:
Fiscalía frena proyecto residencial que se construía ilegalmente en bosque protegido
Se presume que los imputados hicieron incurrir en error a Setena, al presentar una certificación que indicaba que el sitio no correspondía a bosque.
La Fiscalía Ambiental de Osa frenó un desarrollo inmobiliario que se construía ilegalmente en un área de bosque protegido, ubicada dentro del Corredor Biológico Paso La Danta, en Portalón de Savegre, Quepos.
La medida fue ordenada por el Juzgado Penal local, tras confirmarse que el proyecto pretendía levantarse en una zona forestal no autorizada para ese tipo de obras.
"El terreno, que forma parte de un corredor biológico clave para la conservación, había sido presentado ante las autoridades ambientales como apto para construcción.
"No obstante, una inspección realizada por la Fiscalía en conjunto con la Secretaría Técnica Nacional Ambiental (SETENA), desmintió esa versión: el área corresponde efectivamente a bosque", dijo el Ministerio Público.
Además de paralizar las obras, el juzgado ordenó a la empresa responsable eliminar las construcciones realizadas sobre una quebrada, restituir las zonas de protección hídrica y ejecutar obras de mitigación para evitar deslizamientos o derrumbes.
El caso permanece en investigación por los aparentes delitos ambientales de cambio de uso de suelo, tala ilegal, aprovechamiento ilícito de recursos forestales, usurpación de aguas, y falsedad ideológica, entre otros.
"Se presume que los imputados hicieron incurrir en error a Setena al presentar una certificación, la cual indicaba que el sitio no correspondía a bosque y que era apto para construcción", agregó la Fiscalía.
El expediente judicial se tramita bajo el número 24-000079-1111-PE.

author: VNExplorer
title: Judge Aileen Cannon Finds ‘Ridiculous’ Way to Delay Trump’s Case—Again
text: Reuters/Marco Bello Judge Aileen Cannon has cooked up yet another way to slow-walk Donald Trump’s classified documents case, handing the ex-president a partial win Thursday as his lawyers work overtime to delay his trial until after the election. Cannon wrote in an 11-page order that she’d indulge Trump’s lawyers and hold more pre-trial hearings in which they can challenge evidence gathered against Trump in relation to his alleged pilfering of classified documents. The Florida-based district judge, who was appointed by Trump after he lost the 2020 election but before he left office, wrote that “further factual development is warranted” regarding the FBI’s raid on Mar-a-Lago, suggesting she may be receptive to claims from Trump’s lawyers that something is off about the case. It’s a clear win for Trump’s team, who’ve fought tooth and nail to have each of his criminal trials be delayed and delayed again. It’s been nearly two years since FBI agents searched Mar-a-Lago, allegedly uncovering more than 100 classified documents, including in a bathroom, a ballroom, and stashed under dirty golf clothes. Since that raid, Trump has contested that the search warrant was faulty, that agents had no authority to search his South Florida estate, and that investigators improperly breached attorney-client privilege. Now, Trump’s defense will be permitted to make those same arguments in front of Cannon in a hearing. Thursday’s ruling did not list a date for the additional hearings, which likely only adds to prosecutors’ frustration as the trial’s start date has been put on ice indefinitely. Thursday’s decision came just days after Cannon concluded another three-day hearing over prosecutors’ gag order request and Trump’s challenge to the validity of special prosecutors—an issue that had already been ruled on by other courts in the past. She is yet to issue a ruling on either. Cannon, who reportedly refused to recuse herself from the case despite entreaties from two more senior judges, has been repeatedly accused of doing Trump’s bidding. Neama Rahmani, a former federal prosecutor, told The Daily Beast on Tuesday that Cannon is in over her head. “She’s delayed this case and ruled in Trump’s favor at almost every possible turn. She’s entertained arguments that no other judge would,” he said. Joyce Vance, a former U.S. prosecutor, shared similar thoughts in a post to X on Thursday. “The decision to hold an evidentiary hearing after a hearing on legal arguments?” he wrote. “Hard to see that as anything other than sheer delay. Ridiculous.” Steven Cheung, a spokesperson for Trump’s campaign, unsurprisingly praised Cannon’s order in a statement on Thursday, saying she’s a “highly respected” judge and that Trump’s charges are a “political sham.” Read more at The Daily Beast.
